heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
chunks.html_content:
You should have written disciplinary rules and procedures to deal with employee performance and conduct and you must tell your staff about them.

Your rules must say what is acceptable and unacceptable behaviour in the workplace and what action you will take if the rules are broken.

The rules should follow the Acas Code of Practice on disciplinary and grievance procedures.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
You should have written disciplinary rules and procedures to deal with employee performance and conduct and you must tell your staff about them.
Your rules must say what is acceptable and unacceptable behaviour in the workplace and what action you will take if the rules are broken.
The rules should follow the Acas Code of Practice on disciplinary and grievance procedures.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
chunks.html_content: Not following the code is not illegal. However, if someone wins an employment tribunal against you and you did not follow the code, then their award could be up to 25% more.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Not following the code is not illegal. However, if someone wins an employment tribunal against you and you did not follow the code, then their award could be up to 25% more.

chunks.html_content: Your disciplinary procedures should follow the Acas Code of Practice.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Your disciplinary procedures should follow the Acas Code of Practice.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
chunks.html_content: Not following the code is not illegal. However, if someone wins an employment tribunal against you and you did not follow the code, then their award could be up to 25% more.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Not following the code is not illegal. However, if someone wins an employment tribunal against you and you did not follow the code, then their award could be up to 25% more.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Gross misconduct
chunks.html_content:
The exact rules will depend on your organisation, but could cover things like:

  • acceptable and unacceptable behaviour
  • absence and timekeeping
  • health and safety
  • use of phones and the internet

You cannot normally discipline or dismiss an employee for whistleblowing.

Your disciplinary rules should give examples of what will be treated as gross misconduct. This is misconduct judged so serious that its likely to lead to dismissal without notice, for example fraud, theft and physical violence.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Gross misconduct
The exact rules will depend on your organisation, but could cover things like:

  acceptable and unacceptable behaviour
  absence and timekeeping
  health and safety
  use of phones and the internet

You cannot normally discipline or dismiss an employee for whistleblowing.
Your disciplinary rules should give examples of what will be treated as gross misconduct. This is misconduct judged so serious that its likely to lead to dismissal without notice, for example fraud, theft and physical violence.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Telling employees about disciplinary rules
chunks.html_content:
Your disciplinary rules must be in your statement of employment or clearly written elsewhere, such as in a staff handbook.

The rules should clearly say when someone might face disciplinary action and what that action could be.

You must also give the name of someone they should appeal to if theyre unhappy about a disciplinary decision.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Telling employees about disciplinary rules
Your disciplinary rules must be in your statement of employment or clearly written elsewhere, such as in a staff handbook.
The rules should clearly say when someone might face disciplinary action and what that action could be.
You must also give the name of someone they should appeal to if theyre unhappy about a disciplinary decision.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Telling employees about disciplinary rules
chunks.html_content: If you do not provide this information and an employee then wins an employment tribunal claim against you, they could be awarded 2 to 4 weeks pay.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Telling employees about disciplinary rules
If you do not provide this information and an employee then wins an employment tribunal claim against you, they could be awarded 2 to 4 weeks pay.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Disciplinary procedures and contracts
chunks.html_content: If you make your disciplinary procedures part of an employment contract then the employee could make a breach of contract claim against you if you do not follow your procedures.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Disciplinary procedures and contracts
If you make your disciplinary procedures part of an employment contract then the employee could make a breach of contract claim against you if you do not follow your procedures.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Example letters and forms
chunks.html_content: There are a number of sample letters and forms for disciplinary proceedings on the Acas website.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Example letters and forms
There are a number of sample letters and forms for disciplinary proceedings on the Acas website.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
The suggested disciplinary process
chunks.html_content:
The law does not say exactly how you should investigate disciplinary issues or hold disciplinary meetings.

The Acas guidance on discipline and grievances at work has practical advice about running disciplinary proceedings professionally and fairly.

The Acas guidance suggests that your disciplinary process should follow the following format:

  1. A letter telling your employee the issue and inviting them to a disciplinary hearing.

  2. A meeting with your employee to discuss the issue - they should have the right to be accompanied.

  3. A letter to your employee saying what action you are going to take. This should be sent as soon as practically possible.

  4. Your employee should than have a chance to appeal your decision.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
The suggested disciplinary process
The law does not say exactly how you should investigate disciplinary issues or hold disciplinary meetings.
The Acas guidance on discipline and grievances at work has practical advice about running disciplinary proceedings professionally and fairly.
The Acas guidance suggests that your disciplinary process should follow the following format:


A letter telling your employee the issue and inviting them to a disciplinary hearing.


A meeting with your employee to discuss the issue - they should have the right to be accompanied.


A letter to your employee saying what action you are going to take. This should be sent as soon as practically possible.


Your employee should than have a chance to appeal your decision.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Disciplinary decisions
chunks.html_content:
Disciplinary decisions could be anything that could resolve the problem.

This could include:

  • no action
  • written warning
  • final warning
  • demotion
  • dismissal
  • mediation with a co-worker
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
Disciplinary decisions
Disciplinary decisions could be anything that could resolve the problem.
This could include:

  no action
  written warning
  final warning
  demotion
  dismissal
  mediation with a co-worker

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
chunks.html_content:
An employee has the right to appeal against a decision made after a disciplinary hearing.

You should tell them about this when you give them written notice of your decision, and should give them a deadline to tell you they want to appeal.

Your employees statement of terms and conditions of employment must legally include the person they can apply to if they want to appeal a disciplinary decision. It must also explain how to do this.

If the employee does decide to appeal, you should try to hold the appeal hearing as soon as possible.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
An employee has the right to appeal against a decision made after a disciplinary hearing.
You should tell them about this when you give them written notice of your decision, and should give them a deadline to tell you they want to appeal.
Your employees statement of terms and conditions of employment must legally include the person they can apply to if they want to appeal a disciplinary decision. It must also explain how to do this.
If the employee does decide to appeal, you should try to hold the appeal hearing as soon as possible.

heading_context: Taking disciplinary action against an employee
chunks.html_content: You should follow the Acas Code of Practice on disciplinary and grievance procedures when dealing with appeals. Otherwise, if someone wins an employment tribunal against you their award could be higher.
chunks.plain_content:
Taking disciplinary action against an employee
You should follow the Acas Code of Practice on disciplinary and grievance procedures when dealing with appeals. Otherwise, if someone wins an employment tribunal against you their award could be higher.
